original_data.question:
A 25-year-old man presents with painless swelling of the neck for the past week. He reports no recent fevers, night sweats, or weight loss. His past medical history is significant for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, which was diagnosed last year. He also experienced a head trauma 5 years ago, which has been complicated by residual seizures. His only medication is daily phenytoin, which was restarted after he had a seizure 3 months ago. His temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉). On physical examination, multiple non-tender lymph nodes, averaging 2 cm in diameter, are found to be palpable in the anterior and posterior triangles of the neck bilaterally. No other lymphadenopathy is noted. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show the following:
Hemoglobin 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 8000/mm3 with a normal differential
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 40 mm/h
An excisional biopsy of one of the cervical lymph nodes is performed. The histopathologic analysis is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

model_response:
###Rationale: The histopathologic slide shows a classic Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell, which is a large, hyperchromatic, bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli. The cytoplasm is abundant and pale. These cells are usually found in a sea of B cells, which are small lymphocytes with round nuclei and condensed chromatin. This is a diagnostic of classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma (HL). The RS cell is found within a reactive cellular environment consisting of variable proportions of lymphocytes, histiocytes, eosinophils, and plasma cells. The RS cell is derived from the germinal or post-germinal center B cell and is not pathognomonic for HL, as it can be seen in infectious mononucleosis and other mimics. The RS cell in HL is usually found in a sea of B cells, which are small lymphocytes with round nuclei and condensed chromatin. Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) would show a predominance of immature lymphoid cells on the slide. HIV lymphadenopathy would show a predominance of small lymphocytes with dispersed chromatin. Phenytoin-induced adenopathy would show a predominance of histiocytes with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
Perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
Decrease in existing BODY WEIGHT.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Human immunodeficiency virus. A non-taxonomic and historical term referring to any of two species, specifically HIV-1 and/or HIV-2. Prior to 1986, this was called human T-lymphotropic virus type III/lymphadenopathy-associated virus (HTLV-III/LAV). From 1986-1990, it was an official species called HIV. Since 1991, HIV was no longer considered an official species name; the two species were designated HIV-1 and HIV-2.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

Traumatic injuries involving the cranium and intracranial structures (i.e., BRAIN; CRANIAL NERVES; MENINGES; and other structures). Injuries may be classified by whether or not the skull is penetrated (i.e., penetrating vs. nonpenetrating) or whether there is an associated hemorrhage.
Remaining or left behind.

Clinical or subclinical disturbances of cortical function due to a sudden, abnormal, excessive, and disorganized discharge of brain cells. Clinical manifestations include abnormal motor, sensory and psychic phenomena. Recurrent seizures are usually referred to as EPILEPSY or "seizure disorder."
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

An anticonvulsant that is used to treat a wide variety of seizures. It is also an anti-arrhythmic and a muscle relaxant. The mechanism of therapeutic action is not clear, although several cellular actions have been described including effects on ion channels, active transport, and general membrane stabilization. The mechanism of its muscle relaxant effect appears to involve a reduction in the sensitivity of muscle spindles to stretch. Phenytoin has been proposed for several other therapeutic uses, but its use has been limited by its many adverse effects and interactions with other drugs.
To take up or begin anew; resume.

Clinical or subclinical disturbances of cortical function due to a sudden, abnormal, excessive, and disorganized discharge of brain cells. Clinical manifestations include abnormal motor, sensory and psychic phenomena. Recurrent seizures are usually referred to as EPILEPSY or "seizure disorder."
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
An indefinite large quantity that is considered to be greater than several.
They are oval or bean shaped bodies (1 - 30 mm in diameter) located along the lymphatic system.
The length of a straight line passing through the center of a circle or sphere and connecting two points on the circumference.
Of or involving the front of a main body.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
An enlarged lymph node. Causes include viral and bacterial infections and cancers that affect the lymph nodes.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing HEMOGLOBIN whose function is to transport OXYGEN.
The act or process of settling particles by mechanical means from a state of suspension in air or water.
The act of ascertaining or fixing the value or worth of something.
A surgical procedure in which an entire lesion is removed for microscopic examination.
Lymph node groups found within the seven levels and sublevels of the neck. (AJCC 8th ed.)
The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Description:A characteristic representing a single file reference that contains two or more views of the same dosage form of the product; in most cases this should represent front and back views of the dosage form, but occasionally additional views might be needed in order to capture all of the important physical characteristics of the dosage form. Any imprint and/or symbol should be clearly identifiable, and the viewer should not normally need to rotate the image in order to read it. Images that are submitted with SPL should be included in the same directory as the SPL file.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
